thread.title: Ivanka Trump officially recognized as Jewish after guideline change

title: Ivanka Trump officially recognized as Jewish after guideline change

Photo: Evan Vucci, AP Image 1 of / 68 Caption
Close
Image 1 of 68 Ivanka Trump and her husband Jared Kushner dance at the Freedom Ball, in Washington. Is Ivanka Trump really Jewish? Last year, Israel’s religious authorities issued a ruling that raised doubts about her conversion to Judaism. But now that her father is president, they have changed their tune, raising eyebrows among advocates who have long pushed the country’s rabbinical establishment to be more tolerant toward converts.

1) They met because of a networking opportunity:
A mutual friend of the couple thought it would be a good idea for the two to know each other professionally. They fell for each other and now call it the "best deal we ever made"

They met in 2005 and were confirmed to be dating in 2007. During that time mashing together names like Brangelina was popular, thus J-Vanka was born.

Before their wedding in 2009, Ivanka changed her religion from Presbyterian to Judaism, likely because Jared's family objected to her not being Jewish.

Photo: Raymond Hall/GC Images, Getty Images Image 12 of 68 9 Things to know about Ivanka Trump
This week the New York Times wrote about bidding war on a special audience with Ivanka Trump, the daughter of President Donald Trump. One of the top bidders in the charity auction happened to be Russell Ybarra, the owner of the local Tex-Mex empire that includes Gringo’s Mexican Kitchen and Jimmy Changas.
Click through to learn more about President Trump's eldest daughter... less 9 Things to know about Ivanka Trump
This week the New York Times wrote about bidding war on a special audience with Ivanka Trump, the daughter of President Donald Trump. One of the top bidders in the ... more Photo: Andy Katz, MBR Image 13 of 68 | Early years
Ivanka Marie Trump was born on Oct. 30, 1981, the middle child and only daughter of Donald and Ivana Trump. Ivanka is a diminutive of Ivana.
Ivanka Marie Trump was born on Oct. 30, 1981, the middle child and only daughter of Donald and Ivana Trump. Ivanka is a diminutive of Ivana. Photo: Chip Somodevilla, Getty Images Image 14 of 68 | School She attended the Chapin School in New York until she was 15, at which time she was sent to boarding school at Choate-Rosemary Hall in Connecticut. She has called it a "prison."
For college, Ivanka spent two years at Georgetown University before transferring to the University of Pennsylvania, her dad's alma mater.
She graduated with a degree in economics. She speaks English and French, but not much of her mother's native Czech.

"I had very high expectations and they were still surpassed!" she tweeted at the time.

"I had very high expectations and they were still surpassed!" she tweeted at the time. Image 22 of 68 Early years
Melanija Knavs was born April 26, 1970, in what was then a part of Yugoslavia, now Slovenia. Her parents, Viktor and Amalija, were a car and motorcycle dealer for the state and a children's clothing pattern maker. She has a sister and an older half-brother. She is said to be fluent in Slovene, Serbian, French, German and English.
less Early years
Melanija Knavs was born April 26, 1970, in what was then a part of Yugoslavia, now Slovenia. Her parents, Viktor and Amalija, were a car and motorcycle dealer for the state and a children's clothing ... more Photo: Chip Somodevilla, Staff Image 23 of 68 Modeling
Melanija (who later Anglicized her name to Melania Knauss) began modeling at 16. She spent a year at the University of Ljubljana. She obtained a visa to the U.S. in 1996, and although questions have been raised abotu some modeling that voilated the visa, she insists she always abided by the terms of the visa.
Knauss obtained her green card in 2001 and became a citizen in 2006.
In 2000, she posed nude for GQ magazine, a first for a future first lady.

Photo: Cindy Schultz, Staff Photographer Image 68 of 68 Ivanka Trump officially recognized as Jewish after guideline change 1 / 68 Back to Gallery Before getting married in 2009, Ivanka Trump converted to Judaism for her husband Jared Kushner, but adopting the Jewish faith and being recognized as Jewish are two totally different things.
For a person to be recognized as Jewish in Israel, the rabbinic authorities have to officially declare a person as such.
LOOKING FOR TROUBLE: Donald Trump offers to 'destroy' Texas state senator's career for Rockwall sheriff
According to an article on USA Today, the rabbi who oversaw Ivanka's conversion had his credentials questioned, which put into question the validity of her conversion. The Washington Post reported that another conversion by that rabbi was rejected.
However, due to some guideline changes after Trump won the election, Ivanka is now officially recognized as Jewish.
(Story continues below.)
Jared Kushner is the husband of future first daughter Ivanka Trump and a close confidant of her father, President-elect Donald Trump. Here are some things to know about him. Kushner is a New York real estate developer and CEO of a company started by his father. In 2007, at the age of just 26, Kushner purchased a Manhattan office tower, 666 Fifth Avenue, for what was then a record $1.8 billion. Kushner owns The New York Observer newspaper. He met Ivanka Trump over a business lunch. They married on October 25, 2009, in a Jewish ceremony. She converted to Judaism for him. Then-U.S. Atty. Chris Christie prosecuted Charles Kushner on felony charges of witness tampering, illegal campaign donations and tax evasion. After a plea deal, Charles Kushner spent 14 months in federal prison. Jared Kushner is widely suspected of being behind the demotion of Christie on the transition team.
Media: Wibbitz Though chief rabbis say they guidelines were not changed because of the election results, many critics beg to differ.
"It would definitely be embarrassing to the State of Israel and for the rabbinate if the Jewish family like Ivanka Trump's family was to visit Israel and for the official Jewish authorities in Israel to not recognize their Judaism," Elad Kaplan of ITIM, a group that represents Jewish converts in Israel, told USA TODAY .
Despite the controversy, Trump and her husband have long been known for keeping kosher and the Sabbath. Although they received special permission to break the strict observance of the Sabbath for her father's inauguration.
Take a look through the gallery above to see other things you probably didn't know about Ivanka Trump and Jared Kushner.
